subject: Law
title: Universal Declaration of Human Rights
description: A short lesson to help you apply Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

hook.text: In 1948, after the Holocaust, the world agreed: certain rights belong to every person, everywhere.

buildup.text: The UDHR declares 30 fundamental rights: life, liberty, equality, education, work, and freedom from torture.

discovery.text: It was drafted by a committee led by Eleanor Roosevelt and adopted by the UN General Assembly without dissent.

twist.text: The UDHR isn't legally binding as a treaty. But its principles have been incorporated into binding law worldwide.

climax.text: It inspired two binding covenants: the ICCPR (civil and political rights) and ICESCR (economic and social rights).

punchline.text: Thirty rights. One declaration. The foundation of modern human rights.

quiz.question: Is the UDHR legally binding as a treaty?
options: No, but it inspired binding covenants
